bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 25, 1900

div1.p: Reed and Carroll are on board the Sedgewick, bound for Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 25, 1900

opener.dateline:
At sea, off the
Jersey Coast,
Thursday 4 P.M.

div1.p:
As I told
you and dear little piano -
player that you might think
of me on Thursday evening as
the sickest dog “in the bunch”,
I now want to tell you how
splendidly I have made out
thus far. We left N.Y. at 10
a.m.-little daughter's letter-
& your package containing my
overcoat having arrived
about 10 minutes before
the Sedgewick hauled out from
her dock- I was really very
glad to have received them
both, but it was a very
close shave! It was very,
very sweet in my dear wifie
to have sent the coat & very
good & sweet in our little bird=
trainer to have written to her
Papa- The overcoat comes in
so handy, for without it, I
couldn't have sat on the deck
to-night - Just to think that I
haven't been sick a bit, this
time- It's true the sea is quick
but the vessel moves consid-
erably nevertheless, but I don't
mind it a bit - After lunch
which was very appetizing,
I slept from 2 till 5.30 P.M.
& then ate a very hearty
dinner- The fare is very good
and Dr Carroll & I have the
best state-room on the ship,
because I happen to be the
ranking officer aboard- It
seems that state-rooms go
by rank. There are several
officers aboard - Major Peter-
sen of the Commissary Dep't,
Major Dunn & wife, of the
Judge advocates Dep't. and
Lt. Wilcox. I expect to enjoy
the trip very much, as the
bromide appears to be doing
its work beautifully- I so much
wish that my precious ba-
bies knew that their fat
mantee wasn't sick- Indeed
I wish that I had a quart of
Keewaydin strawberries this
very minute; I could eat them
every one! Whether my appe-
tite will be so voracious by
this time Friday evening, I don't
know, but I have every
expectation of being in good
shape- The Sedgwick is at
5 000 tons & was formerly
the City of Chester of the
Inman line - She is a first
class boat & quite fast.
Good-night, you pea and straw
berryes Consumers! For my-
self, I am getting sleepy-
Boo! Boo -- a kiss for
“Tootsey”! What a name
for a puppy -!

A little North of
Jupiter Inlet-
Florida Coast-
SaturdaySunday 11 a.m.

My darling children can see
that there is something of a
gap between my first attempt at
writing & this my second - It
hasn't been altogether due to
seasickness & yet the latter has
had something to do with it -
Although Friday was rough, ac-
cording to my standard, yet I
never felt better- Took my bro-
mide and went to my three meals
& enjoyed them very much - Friday
evening, I promenaded the deck
for an hour with the Captain
although the boat was
pitching a good deal- Indeed, I
couldn't understand my good
feeling at all- When I retired
to my stateroom at 9 o'clock,
I found that Dr Carroll had
given up the fight & surren-
dered to the elements - I sup-
pose that his example had
some effect on me, for I
soon found that it would
be wise policy to return
in as soon as possible-
Saturday morning when I awoke,
there was a sensation of
two or three tons of brick
in the region of the stomach &
an entire loss of appitite.
The boat was rolling and
the orange that I ate soon
began to roll, too, until it
rolled out! This will ac-
count for my failure to add
any to my letter on Friday evening,
as I had intended, or on Saturday-
Indeed I staid in my berth all
day yesterday - read some, slept
more & “fed the fishes” as occasion
seemed to require! Still the day
wasn't, all things taken, a very dis-
agreeable one- This morning, I have
had an orange, a cup of black
coffee & a piece of dry toast,-have
taken a good sponge bath, put
on thinner underwear, & have come
on deck to enjoy the delightful
breeze - am feeling very well,
all things considered and think
that I can make out very well till
tomorrow, when we reach Havana.
At 8.30 this morning, I thought of
my babies sitting down to break-
fast and oh! how I did want some
of those fresh strawberries! For I
imagine that you picked some just
before breakfast- I hope that you
didn't spoil them by putting sugar
on them! and Oh! for just one cup
of that good coffee! and a taste
of those cabbage! I should be
well immediately. Do write & tell
me how the things grow, both
flowers & vegetables, for I shall
take such interest in them- I
can almost hear little joy playing
on her piano- Bless your
darling hearts, how I shall look
forward to seeing you in August!

We are now skirting along the
Florida Coast, running parallel
at a distance of about two
miles - you can hardly imagine
how refreshing the sight of the beach
and the foliage is, after 48 hours
at sea. The strip of green, seen
over the water, is so pleasant
a prospect - just now we came
abreast of Palm Beach Hotel
and the Royal Ponciana, on
Lake North - with Dr Carroll's
opera glasses, I could see every
part of the buildings & cottages
perfectly- Some winter we
must come down & enjoy the
climate & beach - nestling here
and there amongst the pines
I can see many pretty homes.
Twice, this morning, we have
seen a beautiful rain passing up
the coast just parallel with the
shore, and each time have felt
its refreshing coolness- The
weather, by the way, has thus
far been delightful - not at
all warm. We are now
scudding along at a 15 knot
rate with a most delight-
ful breeze fanning our cheeks.
The Gong has sounded for
lunch, but I won't go down.
I don't feel a particle sick,
and for that very reason I
will have my lunch served
on deck, for I am afraid that
the sight of so much food and the
odor of the ship would turn me
up side down. How dear little
daughter would enjoy seeing the
schools of flying fish, as they
suddenly rise out of the water
and go hurrying along, appa-
rently to get rid of the ship-
we are continually seeing them-
Thursday afternoon a school
of porpoises made sport for
us for quite a while, as
they went rolling and diving and
chasing after each other.
I wonder whether you are
enjoying as delightful a
breeze at dear Keewaydin
as we are now having -
Tell daughter that as I write
the Captain's little Fox-terrier
stands and gazes wishfully at
me, as if she wanted to get into
my lap- She reminds me very
much of “Tootsey” - Why didn't
cousin Annie name that pup
“Wootsey”? or better still “Toot-
sey - Wootsey”? Isn't it nice
that auntie is coming up so
soon? Has Mary come over
yet? Did Mr Moore conclude
to take the pony? Dear me,
I will have to bring this
letter to a close or else I
won't have any thing to put
in the next one- I'll try to fin-
ish it just before we reach
Havana & then mail it promptly
so that you can get it by Thursday.

Not quite in sight
of Cuba, Monday Morning,
7.30 o'clock-

Well, sweetest children on earth,
here is your old Mr Mantee
up at this hour on the Saloon
deck, after having sucked a lemon
dry, swallowed a glass of cracked
ice, and shaved himself in the
most approved style. What do
you think of such an outburst
of energy? Pretty good for a
man who isn't much of a sailor?
The day passed off beautifully
yesterday - delicious breezes,
slightly clouded skies, and the fringe
of green, on our starboard
side, of Florida's Coast- We
did not leave it till late
in the afternoon, and even after
night came on we still saw
its light-houses, so that I didn't
feel very far from dear Kee-
waydin and its precious in-
habitants - we sat on deck
till 10.30 P.M.: saw a steamer
with all lights set making for
a northern port, on the one
side, and a U.S. Revenue
Cutter, with her big search
light, on the other, looking for
smugglers along the Florida
Keys -- I then went below &
by means of an Electric Fan
and a wind-scoop in each of
our two port- holes, managed
to woo a good breeze
which stayed with us the whole
night, so that we slept well
& both feel refreshed, this
morning- The sea is still
very quiet, so that there is
no motion hardly too the big
ship- I shall certainly select
her for my return trip.

The weather is warmer than
at our dear little mountain
home, and I expect that we
will find it still warmer
when we reach the shore.
We expect to enter the Harbor
about 10 a.m. & I am so
anxious to get my letter in
the 12 o'clock mail, in which
case my darling wifie & daughter
would get this by Thursday
Evening- How is everything at
dear Keewaydin this bright morn-
ing? I hope very well and
happy- I know that the straw-
berries must be at their best,
and that the pansies & astors
are just booming - I would give
a dollar for a gourd of that
delicious water! 9.15 a.m-
Moro Castle is just sighted, so that
we will be at anchor about 11 a.m.
The Cuban Coast is looming up
very prettily & I must bring my
effort to a close. We will re-
port to Gen. Wood, this forenoon,
& then go out to Quemados, this after-
noon- Am very well- Love and a
thousand kisses for my precious strawberry
picker & piano-player.
